slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about the problem our character has. Is something lost? Did they hear a funny noise? We can use special words to show how they feel, like maybe their tummy feels wiggly or their heart goes thump-thump-thump.

slides.text: 'Characters can TALK in your story. When they do, put quotation marks around their words: "I have to find the key!" said Maya. "But where could it be?"'
slides.mascot_explanation: When characters talk in our stories, we put little marks, like tiny ears, around their words! So if your character says something, we'll put those marks around what they say, like "I need to be brave!"

slides.text: 'Now write the CLIMAX — the most exciting moment! This is where the character faces the biggest challenge. What happens?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we write the CLIMAX! This is the super-duper, most exciting part of the whole story, like the highest point on a roller coaster! It's when our character has to be the bravest or figure something out.

slides.prompt: Write the middle and climax of your story. Include at least one line of dialogue. Make the reader feel excited or worried. Write at least 5-6 sentences.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part – we get to write our own story! Let's write at least five or six sentences about the problem and the big exciting moment. We can even make our characters talk to each other using those special quotation marks we learned.

slides.text: 'Read your story out loud from the beginning. How does it sound? Tomorrow you will write the ending and finish your story!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a story middle that introduces a problem and builds toward a climax, using some dialogue?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You wrote the exciting middle and the super-climactic part of your story! Now let's read the whole thing from the very beginning to hear how amazing it sounds. Tomorrow, we'll write the very end!

parent_notes: Writing the middle of a story is the hardest part for young writers — beginnings are exciting and endings are satisfying, but middles require sustained effort and plot development. Help the child refer back to their planning sheet when they feel stuck. The introduction of dialogue marks (quotation marks) adds complexity; keep it simple — just put the marks around what the character says. If the child struggles with spelling during drafting, encourage them to write the sounds they hear and move on. The goal is creative flow, not perfect mechanics. Reading aloud is essential — the child hears awkward phrasing and can self-correct.

title: Division — Introduction to Remainders
description: The child encounters division problems that do not divide evenly, discovering the concept of remainders. Using concrete materials, they see that sometimes there are 'leftovers' that cannot be shared equally.
instructions:
1. Set up 7 objects (counters, beads) and 2 bowls.
2. 'Let's share 7 equally between 2. Give one to this bowl, one to that bowl...'
3. Count: each bowl has 3. One is left over! 'This leftover is called a REMAINDER.'
4. Write: 7 ÷ 2 = 3 remainder 1 (or 3 R1).
5. Try more: 10 ÷ 3 = 3 R1. 13 ÷ 4 = 3 R1. 17 ÷ 5 = 3 R2.
6. 'The remainder is always LESS than the number you are dividing by. Why?'
7. Challenge: 'Can you find a division problem with NO remainder?'

slides.heading: Division
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this big word: "Division"! It just means sharing things. And we're going to learn about something super cool called "remainders" – they're like little leftovers!

slides.setup_instructions: Set out counters and bowls on the mat. Have paper ready for recording.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get ready for our sharing game! We need lots of little things to share, like these colorful beads, and some little bowls to put them in. We also need paper and a pencil to write down our answers, and this big mat to keep everything tidy. Can you ask a grown-up to help you gather all these fun things?

slides.text: 'Let's share 7 counters equally between 2 bowls. One for you, one for you, one for you, one for you... 3 each! But one is LEFT OVER.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pretend we have 7 yummy candies and we want to share them with 2 friends. Watch me! We give one candy to this friend, then one to that friend, and we keep going until we can't share anymore. See? Each friend gets 3 candies, but oh no! There's 1 candy left all by itself.

slides.text: 'This leftover is called a REMAINDER. We write it like this: 7 divided by 2 equals 3, remainder 1. We could not share that last one equally.'
slides.mascot_explanation: That one candy that's all by itself is called a "remainder." It means we couldn't share it equally with our friends. So, we say 7 candies shared between 2 friends is 3 candies each, with 1 remainder!

slides.text: 'Let's try more. 10 counters shared among 3 bowls. Deal them out... 3 each, and 1 left over! 10 ÷ 3 = 3 R1.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try another one! We have 10 little toys to share between 3 friends. We give one to each friend, then another, then another... Look! Each friend gets 3 toys, and there's still 1 toy left over. So, 10 toys shared by 3 friends is 3 toys each, with 1 remainder!

slides.text: 'Notice: the remainder is always SMALLER than the number of bowls. Why? Because if you had enough left over to give one more to each bowl, you would!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it funny how the leftover piece is always smaller than the groups we're making? If we had enough left over to give one more to each friend, we would! That's why it's called a remainder – it's what's left after we share as much as we can equally.

slides.prompt: Try these: 13 ÷ 4, 17 ÷ 5, 11 ÷ 3, 15 ÷ 4. Use counters and bowls. Write each answer with the remainder. Find one problem with no remainder!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the sharer! Let's try sharing 13 things into 4 groups, and then 17 things into 5 groups. Use your beads and bowls, and write down your answers. Can you find a way to share everything so there are NO leftovers at all?

slides.text: 'Sometimes things divide evenly, and sometimes there are remainders. Both are perfectly fine! In real life, remainders happen all the time — like when you have 7 cookies and 2 friends.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child divide concretely and correctly identify the remainder? Do they understand that the remainder must be less than the divisor?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job sharing and finding those remainders! Sometimes we share things and have leftovers, and sometimes we share them perfectly. It's like sharing cookies – sometimes there's one left for you! You were so clever figuring out how the leftovers work.

parent_notes: Remainders are a concept that confuses many older students because they first encounter it abstractly. By introducing it concretely — physically dealing out objects and seeing what is left — the child develops an intuitive understanding. The key insight is: the remainder must always be less than the divisor, because if it were equal or larger, you could distribute more. Let the child discover this rather than stating it. Real-world connections: sharing snacks, dealing cards, dividing into teams. You might ask: 'If there are 7 cookies and 2 people, what happens to the remainder cookie?' This can lead to delightful discussions about fairness (split it in half — which is a fraction!).

title: Healthy Eating — Nutrients and Food Groups
description: Building on the digestive system lesson, the child learns about the five food groups and basic nutrients. They analyze a day's meals and create a balanced plate using the food group model.
instructions:
1. 'We learned how food travels through your body. But WHY does your body need food? For NUTRIENTS!'
2. Introduce the five food groups: fruits, vegetables, grains, protein, dairy.
3. For each group, explain what it gives the body: energy (grains), building muscles (protein), strong bones (dairy), vitamins (fruits/vegetables).
4. Show a balanced plate diagram (half fruits/vegetables, quarter grains, quarter protein, side of dairy).
5. The child sorts food pictures or real foods into groups.
6. Plan and draw a balanced meal for each food group.
7. 'Your digestive system breaks down these foods so your body can use the nutrients!'
materials_needed: Food group chart or printed diagram
Food pictures (cut from magazines or printed)

slides.heading: Healthy Eating
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! We're going to learn all about healthy eating today! It's super important for our bodies to grow big and strong, and we'll find out all the yummy ways food helps us.

slides.setup_instructions: Print or draw a food group chart. Cut out food pictures from magazines or print from the internet. Have a paper plate for the balanced meal activity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these things we need for our activity! We have a special chart showing the food groups, fun pictures of food, a paper plate to make our meal, and colorful pencils to draw. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things so we can get started!

slides.text: 'Remember our digestive system lesson? Your body breaks down food to get NUTRIENTS — the building blocks your body needs to grow, move, and think!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned food goes on a journey in our tummy? Well, our body takes that food and breaks it into tiny pieces called nutrients! These nutrients are like special building blocks that help us run, jump, and even think super smart thoughts!

slides.text: 'There are five food groups: FRUITS, VEGETABLES, GRAINS (bread, rice, pasta), PROTEIN (meat, beans, eggs, nuts), and DAIRY (milk, cheese, yogurt).'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's meet the food friends! We have yummy fruits, crunchy vegetables, grains like bread, protein like chicken or beans, and dairy like milk and cheese. Each one is special and helps our body in a different way.

slides.text: 'Each group gives your body different nutrients. Protein builds muscles. Grains give energy. Dairy builds strong bones. Fruits and vegetables give vitamins that fight sickness.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, what do these food friends do? Protein helps build strong muscles so you can be a super jumper! Grains give you energy for playing all day long. Dairy makes your bones super strong, and fruits and veggies help keep yucky sickness away!

slides.text: 'A balanced plate has food from all five groups! Half your plate should be fruits and vegetables, one quarter grains, one quarter protein, with dairy on the side.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this plate! This is what a super healthy meal looks like. See how it's half fruits and veggies? Then we have a little bit of grains and protein, and some dairy too. It’s like a rainbow of yummy food!

slides.prompt: Create a balanced meal on your paper plate! Cut and glue food pictures or draw foods from each group. Label each food group. Make it a meal you would actually want to eat!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to make a super yummy and healthy plate! You can cut out pictures of food or draw your favorites and put them on the paper plate. Let's try to put a little bit from each food group on there, just like our special plate picture.

slides.text: 'When you eat foods from all five groups, you give your body everything it needs! Tomorrow's cooking lesson will put this knowledge into practice.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name the five food groups, sort foods correctly, and create a balanced plate?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job making your healthy plate! You learned all about the five food groups and how they help your body. Eating all these different foods gives your body the best fuel to play and learn!

parent_notes: This lesson connects directly to the digestive system lesson from Day 2, completing the picture: the digestive system is the HOW, and nutrients are the WHY. The Montessori approach to nutrition is practical — the child learns about food groups not as abstract knowledge but as a guide for real meals they eat and prepare. When creating the balanced plate, let the child choose foods they enjoy — the goal is understanding the framework, not prescribing specific foods. Avoid language of 'good food' and 'bad food' — instead use 'everyday foods' and 'sometimes foods.' Connect to practical life: 'When you plan your snack, can you include two food groups?'
household_substitutes: Food group chart or printed diagram
Food pictures (cut from magazines or printed)
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Musical Composition — Creating a Simple Song
description: The child composes a simple song using their homemade instrument and voice. They create lyrics, a melody, and a rhythmic pattern, integrating language arts, mathematics (rhythm patterns), and creative expression.
instructions:
1. 'Musicians create songs with three parts: LYRICS (words), MELODY (the tune), and RHYTHM (the beat pattern).'
2. Start with lyrics: write a short verse about something meaningful (family, nature, a favorite thing). 4 lines is enough.
3. Create a simple melody: hum different tunes until one feels right with the words.
4. Add rhythm on the homemade instrument: create a repeating pattern (tap-tap-rest, tap-tap-rest).
5. Practice the whole song together: singing the lyrics to the melody while keeping rhythm.
6. Perform for the family!

slides.heading: Musical Composition
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! We're going to be super songwriters today and make our very own song! It's going to be so much fun to create something brand new with words and music.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the instrument from the sound exploration lesson ready. Sit in a comfortable, inspiring spot.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's see what we need for our songwriting adventure! We need that special instrument we made before, and some paper and a pencil so we can write down our song ideas. If you have any other fun sound makers, you can get those too!

slides.text: 'Songwriters create music in three parts: LYRICS are the words, MELODY is the tune you sing, and RHYTHM is the beat. Today you will write all three!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Did you know that songs have three special parts? We have the words, called lyrics, and the happy tune we sing, called a melody, and then there's the beat, like a little drum, called rhythm. Today, we get to make all three parts for our own song!

slides.text: 'Start with words. What do you want your song to be about? Write 4 lines. They can rhyme but they do not have to!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to start with the words for our song! What's something you really love, like your family or a pretty flower? Let's write down just four short lines about it to start our song.

slides.text: 'Now hum a tune — try different melodies until one feels right with your words. There is no wrong answer! Sing the words with your melody.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to find the perfect tune for your words! Try humming different little songs until you find one that feels just right with the words you wrote. Sing your words with your new melody and see how it sounds!

slides.text: 'Add your instrument! Create a repeating rhythm pattern that goes with your song. Practice putting it all together: lyrics, melody, and rhythm.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's make some noise with our instrument! We'll pick a beat, like a little pattern, that we can play over and over again. Then, we'll put the words, the tune, and the beat all together to make our song sound amazing!

slides.prompt: Write your lyrics, create a melody, and add a rhythm. Practice your song until you can perform it all the way through. Then perform for your family!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You wrote your words, found a special tune, and added a cool beat. Now, let's practice singing your whole song, and then you can sing it for your family to hear how wonderful it is!

slides.text: 'You are a songwriter! You created something that never existed before — lyrics, melody, and rhythm that are completely yours.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create and perform a simple song with original lyrics, a melody, and rhythmic accompaniment?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are an amazing songwriter! You made up brand new words, a special tune, and a fun beat all by yourself. That's like magic, creating something that wasn't here before!

parent_notes: Musical composition is deeply creative and often intimidating for adults, but children approach it with natural freedom. The key is removing the idea that there is a 'right' way to write a song. Encourage every attempt enthusiastically. If the child struggles with melody, suggest they modify a familiar tune (singing new words to 'Twinkle Twinkle' is a legitimate songwriting technique). The rhythm work connects to math — repeating patterns, counting beats. If the child is hesitant to perform, let them record it privately first. The performance is important because it builds the confidence to share creative work, which connects to next week's oral presentation skills.
household_substitutes: Pots, pans, wooden spoons for rhythm
preparation_steps: Gather sound-making objects. Choose a space where noise is okay.
control_of_error: Can the child repeat a rhythm pattern? Can they keep a steady beat?
extension_ideas: Create a simple song together
Clap rhythm patterns for each other to copy
Listen to different genres and compare

title: Cooking from a Recipe Card — Independent Meal Preparation
description: The child independently follows a recipe card to prepare a simple, healthy meal or substantial snack. This integrates reading, math (measurement), nutrition knowledge, and all practical life skills developed throughout the year.
instructions:
1. Present 2-3 recipe cards with pictures and simple text (e.g., quesadillas, pasta with vegetables, fruit and yogurt parfait).
2. The child reads the recipe card independently.
3. 'Gather all your ingredients first. Check them off the list.'
4. The child follows the steps: measuring, mixing, assembling, cooking (with supervision for heat).
5. 'Set the table for the meal you prepared.'
6. Serve and eat together.
7. The child cleans up: washes dishes, wipes counters, puts away ingredients.
materials_needed: All ingredients for the chosen recipe

slides.heading: Independent Cooking
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says we're going to be super chefs today and make our own yummy food all by ourselves, just by following a special recipe card!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare recipe cards with pictures and simple text. Ensure all ingredients are available. The child will gather them independently.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need! We have recipe cards with pictures, all the yummy food ingredients, special cups and spoons for measuring, and tools to help us mix and stir. We'll also need our apron to keep our clothes clean and things to make our table look nice for eating!

slides.text: 'Today you are the chef! Choose a recipe card and read it carefully. What ingredients do you need? What tools?'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be a chef and pick out what we want to make! Look at the pictures on the recipe cards and read the words to choose your yummy food, and then tell us what ingredients and tools you need.

slides.text: 'Before you start cooking, gather EVERYTHING you need. Professional chefs call this MISE EN PLACE — everything in its place.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Chefs are super organized, and we need to be too! Let's gather *everything* on our recipe card before we even start cooking, so everything is ready when we need it.

slides.text: 'Now follow the steps, one by one. Read each step, do it, then move to the next. Measure carefully — cooking is like a science experiment!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's follow the recipe, step by step, just like a treasure map! Read one part, do it carefully, then read the next part and do that. Measuring is like a fun science experiment to make sure our food tastes just right!

slides.text: 'When your food is ready, set the table beautifully. Then serve your creation!
slides.mascot_explanation: Your yummy food is almost ready! Now, let's make our table look super pretty with our special setting items, and then we can put your amazing food right in the middle to eat!

slides.prompt: Follow your recipe card from start to finish. Gather ingredients, measure, prepare, cook (with adult help for hot items), set the table, and serve.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to be a chef from start to finish! We'll gather our food, measure it, mix it up, cook it (with a grown-up's help for hot things!), set the table, and then eat our delicious meal!

slides.text: 'You just prepared a meal by yourself! Clean up your workspace — a good chef always leaves the kitchen clean. You used reading, math, and science all in one activity!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently read a recipe, gather materials, follow steps in order, measure accurately, and complete the meal with cleanup?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You made your own yummy food all by yourself! Now, let's be super chefs and clean up our kitchen, putting everything away and wiping the counters. You were so smart using your reading and measuring skills today!

parent_notes: Independent cooking is the ultimate practical life integration — it requires reading (the recipe), math (measuring), science (heat changes food), sequencing, fine motor skills, and self-management. By this point in the year, the child should be able to handle most steps independently, with adult supervision only for safety around heat and sharp tools. Mise en place (gathering everything before starting) is a genuine culinary practice that teaches planning and organization. Let the child problem-solve: if they cannot find an ingredient, what could they substitute? If they make a measurement error, what happens? These real-world consequences teach more than any worksheet.
household_substitutes: Ingredients as listed in the lesson
preparation_steps: Wash hands first. Set out all ingredients and tools before calling the child. Pre-wash produce.
control_of_error: The finished food item shows the result. Taste-testing is the best self-check!
extension_ideas: Let the child serve the food to family
Draw or write about what you made
Try a variation with different ingredients

title: Creative Writing — Writing the Ending and Illustrating the Story
description: The child completes their short story by writing the resolution and ending, then creates a cover and illustrations. The finished product is a complete authored and illustrated book.
instructions:
1. Review the story so far by reading it aloud.
2. 'Your character faced a big problem. How does it get SOLVED?'
3. The child writes the resolution and ending (at least 4-5 sentences).
4. 'Every story needs a satisfying ending. Does the character learn something? Change? Celebrate?'
5. Create a front cover: Title, 'Written and Illustrated by [child's name]', cover illustration.
6. Add 2-3 illustrations throughout the story.
7. Staple or bind the pages into a book.
8. Read the complete story aloud to the family.
materials_needed: Blank paper for cover and illustrations

slides.heading: Creative Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! We're going to be authors and artists today and make our very own book! We'll write the end of our story and make it look super special.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the story draft ready. Provide blank paper for the cover and illustrations. Set up a binding station.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our super important book-making supplies ready! We have your story so far, some paper for writing, some special paper for the cover, colorful pencils to draw with, and a stapler to hold it all together. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these things so we can start making magic!

slides.text: 'Let's read your story from the beginning. Listen to how it flows... Now, how does your character solve the problem?'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we're going to read the story you've already written. Listen carefully, and then we'll think about the big problem your character had. How will they fix it and make everything all better?

slides.text: 'Write the solution and the ending. A great ending makes the reader feel satisfied. Maybe the character learned something important, or maybe they celebrate!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to write the super exciting part – how your character solves their problem and what happens at the very end! Think about if your character learned something new or if they had a big happy celebration. This is how we make our story feel all finished and wonderful.

slides.text: 'Now make your book! Create a front cover with the title and 'Written and Illustrated by [your name].' Draw a cover picture that makes people want to read your book.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Every amazing book needs a cool cover! We'll make one with a title, say that YOU wrote and drew it, and add a picture that makes everyone want to open our book. It's like giving our story a happy, welcoming hug!

slides.text: 'Add illustrations to your favorite scenes. Then we will bind all the pages together into a real book!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun pictures! We'll add drawings to your favorite parts of the story to make it even more exciting. Then, we'll put all your pages together with the stapler so it's a real book you can hold!

slides.prompt: Write the ending, create the cover, add illustrations, and bind your book. Then read your complete story aloud to the family!
slides.mascot_explanation: We have 25 minutes to finish making our book! Let's finish writing the end, draw our cover and pictures, and put it all together. Then, the very best part: we get to read our whole story to our family!

slides.text: 'You are an AUTHOR and ILLUSTRATOR! You planned, drafted, and completed an entire story. This book is yours — you created it from nothing but your imagination.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a complete story with beginning, middle, and end, create a cover and illustrations, and read it aloud?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Look at your amazing book! You are a real author and a super artist because you thought of everything and made this whole story by yourself. You created this whole wonderful book from your amazing imagination!

parent_notes: Completing a book is a major achievement. The child has engaged in the full writing process: planning (graphic organizer), drafting (beginning, middle, end across three days), and publishing (cover, illustrations, binding). Celebrate this accomplishment genuinely — the child has done something many adults find challenging. When the child reads aloud to the family, give full attention and applause. This book should go in the portfolio as a prime example of year-end language capability. Resist the urge to correct spelling or grammar in the final product — the child's voice and creativity matter more than mechanical perfection at this stage. If the child wants to make a 'clean copy,' support that impulse, but do not require it.

title: Word Problems — All Four Operations
description: The child solves word problems that require determining which operation to use: addition, subtraction, multiplication, or division. This develops mathematical reasoning and real-world application of all arithmetic skills.
instructions:
1. 'Today you will solve real-life math problems! The tricky part: you have to figure out WHICH operation to use.'
2. Problem 1 (addition): 'There are 145 red beads and 237 blue beads. How many beads altogether?'
3. Problem 2 (subtraction): 'You had 84 stickers and gave 37 to your friend. How many do you have now?'
4. Problem 3 (multiplication): 'There are 4 tables with 6 chairs each. How many chairs total?'
5. Problem 4 (division): 'You have 20 cookies to share equally among 5 friends. How many does each friend get?'
6. For each: 'What operation will you use? How do you know?'
7. Solve with materials (stamp game, counters) or on paper.

slides.heading: Word Problems
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title slide! We're going to learn how to solve real-life math puzzles using addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. It's like being a math detective!

slides.setup_instructions: Write 6-8 word problems on cards. Have materials available for solving.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we get to use! We have these cards with stories on them, and we can use these little blocks or paper to help us figure out the answers. We'll also use paper and a pencil, and maybe even a special mat to work on. Ask your grown-up to help you get all these ready for our math adventure!

slides.text: 'Math is not just about numbers — it helps us solve real problems! Today, read each problem and decide: should you ADD, SUBTRACT, MULTIPLY, or DIVIDE?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide tells us that math is super helpful for real life! We're going to read some stories and then use our smart brains to pick the right math tool: adding, taking away, making groups, or sharing. It's like choosing the perfect crayon for a picture!

slides.text: 'Clue words help: ALTOGETHER and TOTAL often mean addition. LEFT and REMAINING mean subtraction. EACH and GROUPS mean multiplication or division.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, special words in the stories give us a hint! Words like "altogether" or "total" often mean we need to add. If a story says "left" or "how many now," we might need to subtract. And words like "each" or "groups" can mean we multiply or divide. These are like secret clues!

slides.text: 'Try this: There are 145 red beads and 237 blue beads. How many altogether? What operation? Yes — addition! Solve it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try this problem together! It says there are red beads and blue beads, and we need to find out how many altogether. Since we want to know the total number, we need to add them up! Can you help me figure out how many beads there are?

slides.text: 'Now: You have 20 cookies for 5 friends. How many each? What operation? Division! 20 divided by 5 equals 4.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This next story is about yummy cookies! We have 20 cookies and we want to share them equally with 5 friends. When we share things equally, we use division. So, we need to figure out how many cookies each friend gets.

slides.prompt: Solve 6 word problems. For each one, write which operation you chose and why, then solve it. Use materials if you need them.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the math detective! We have 6 more story problems to solve. For each one, you'll read it, pick the right math tool (add, subtract, multiply, or divide), and then find the answer. You can use our special blocks or paper to help you!

slides.text: 'You can use all four operations to solve real problems! The most important skill is reading carefully and thinking: what is this problem really asking me to do?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the correct operation for different word problem types and solve them accurately?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You solved all those tricky word problems and used all four math tools! You are so good at reading carefully and figuring out what the problem is asking. You’re a super math star!

parent_notes: Word problems are the bridge between mathematical operations and real-world application. The most common struggle is not the computation but determining which operation to use. Teaching 'clue words' (altogether = add, remaining = subtract, each/groups = multiply, share equally = divide) gives the child a strategy. However, over-reliance on clue words can be misleading — ultimately the child needs to understand the SITUATION. Ask: 'Are we putting groups together or taking apart? Are we making equal groups or sharing into equal groups?' If the child can solve the computation but chooses the wrong operation, focus on comprehension, not calculation. Use the stamp game or counters for computation to keep the focus on reasoning.

title: Family Heritage Project — Creating a Family Heritage Poster
description: The child compiles information from the family interview and name exploration to create a beautiful family heritage poster. This integrates cultural knowledge, artistic expression, and writing skills into a meaningful portfolio piece.
instructions:
1. Review the interview notes from Day 3 and the name art from Day 1 (read-aloud extension).
2. 'Today you will create a poster that celebrates your family heritage!'
3. Include: Family name origin and meaning, family traditions, a family recipe or special food, places the family has lived, a favorite family story.
4. The child writes and illustrates each section on a large poster.
5. Add photos (printed), drawings, or decorative borders.
6. Optional: include a small family tree (parents, grandparents).
7. Display the poster and present it to the family.
materials_needed: Large poster board or construction paper

slides.heading: Family Heritage Project
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to make a super special poster all about your family. It's like making a treasure map of all the wonderful things that make your family YOU!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the large poster board. Gather all notes, photos, and art supplies. Plan the layout before gluing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our art supplies ready! We have a big poster board, which is like a giant piece of paper for our art. We also have colorful pencils and markers to draw with, and some glue to stick things down. If you have special pictures of your family, we can add those too! Ask a grown-up to help you find everything so we can start making our poster!

slides.text: 'All week you have been learning about your family and heritage. Today you will put it all together into a beautiful poster!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We've been learning so many cool things about your family this week, haven't we? Today is so exciting because we get to put all those amazing discoveries onto our big poster to show everyone!

slides.text: 'Your poster will include: your family name and its meaning, traditions your family has, a favorite family story from your interview, and places your family has lived.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our poster will tell a story! We'll write about your family's special name and what it means, fun things your family likes to do together, a super interesting story your family told you, and even places your family used to live.

slides.text: 'Plan your layout first — where will each section go? Leave space for illustrations and decorations. Write a title at the top.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Before we start drawing and gluing, let's think about where everything will go on our poster. We can make a title at the top, like "My Awesome Family," and then decide where to put the pictures and writing for each part.

slides.text: 'Now fill in each section. Write neatly, draw illustrations, add photos or decorative borders. Make it beautiful and meaningful!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun part! We get to fill in each section of our poster with our own words and drawings. You can write about your family name, draw a picture of a family tradition, and make it look so pretty with colors and maybe even some sparkly decorations!

slides.prompt: Create your family heritage poster with at least 4 sections: family name, traditions, a family story, and where your family is from. Illustrate each section.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's make our awesome family poster! We need to make sure we have at least four parts: your family name, something special your family does, a fun story, and where your family comes from. Then, let's draw a picture for each part to make it extra special! You can do it!

slides.text: 'Your heritage poster tells the story of YOUR family! Display it where everyone can see it. Every family has a unique and wonderful story.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child compile family information into an organized, illustrated poster that communicates their heritage?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your amazing poster! It's like a beautiful storybook all about your family, and you made it! Let's hang it up somewhere everyone can see how wonderful your family is. You did such a great job sharing your family's special story!

parent_notes: The family heritage poster is a culminating project that brings together the week's cultural explorations. It becomes a cherished family document as well as a portfolio piece. Help the child organize the information but let them make design choices. If your family has a complex or sensitive history (adoption, divorce, immigration struggles), frame everything positively: every family has a story worth honoring, and that story is always evolving. The act of creating this poster teaches the child that their family matters, their history is worth documenting, and they are connected to something larger than themselves. Display it prominently!
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
extension_ideas: Draw a favorite scene
Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together

title: Read-Aloud: Thank You, Mr. Falker by Patricia Polacco
description: The autobiographical story of Patricia Polacco's struggle with reading difficulty and the teacher who finally helped her learn to read. Themes of perseverance, the power of a caring teacher, and the joy of overcoming challenges.
instructions:
1. 'This is a TRUE story about the author — Patricia Polacco. When she was young, she could not learn to read.'
2. Read the story, noting the emotional journey: excitement about school, frustration with reading, bullying, and finally the breakthrough with Mr. Falker.
3. Pause at the bullying scene: 'How does Trisha feel? Why is reading so important to her?'
4. After the breakthrough: 'How did Mr. Falker help? What changed?'
5. Connect to the child: 'What is something that was hard for YOU that you can do now?'
6. Discuss perseverance and the importance of not giving up.
7. Write or draw: 'Something I worked hard to learn.'
materials_needed: Thank You, Mr. Falker by Patricia Polacco

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Thank You, Mr. Falker by Patricia Polacco
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to read a very special book today called "Thank You, Mr. Falker." It's a story about a real person named Patricia Polacco, who wrote and drew this book.

items: Thank You, Mr. Falker by Patricia Polacco
slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably together. This is an emotional book — be prepared for meaningful conversation.
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready for our story, we need a few things! We need the book itself, some paper for drawing, and some pencils and colorful crayons. Ask your grown-up to help you find these so we can start our fun.

slides.text: 'This is a true story. Patricia Polacco — the woman who wrote and drew all those beautiful books we love — could not read when she was young. This is her story.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This story is super special because it's about the author herself, Patricia Polacco! When she was little, just like you, reading was really, really tricky for her. But she was very smart and just needed a little help.

slides.text: Read the story. Pause at the honey on the book: 'In Trisha's family, a book is dipped in honey because learning is sweet.' Pause at the bullying: 'How does Trisha feel?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to read the story together! We'll see how Patricia felt when reading was hard, and we'll learn about a kind teacher who helped her. Pay close attention to how she feels when things get tough, and what happens when she finally learns to read!

slides.text: 'Mr. Falker saw that Trisha was smart but needed help reading in a different way. He never gave up on her. What happened when she finally could read?'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this part? It talks about a teacher named Mr. Falker. He was very smart and knew just how to help Patricia learn to read. What amazing thing happened after Mr. Falker helped her learn?

slides.text: 'Think about something that was hard for you — maybe reading, or math, or riding a bike. You kept trying, and you learned! That is called PERSEVERANCE.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Can you think of something that used to be hard for you, but now you can do it? Maybe learning to tie your shoes or ride your bike! When you keep trying and trying, even when it's tough, that's called being super brave and never giving up.

slides.prompt: Draw and write about something that was hard for you at first but you learned to do through practice and perseverance. How did it feel when you finally could do it?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to show me what you learned! We're going to draw a picture of something that was hard for you, but you practiced and practiced until you could do it. Tell me how it felt when you finally did it!

slides.text: 'Patricia Polacco grew up to write and illustrate over 100 books. The girl who could not read became one of the most beloved authors. Never give up on yourself.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the theme of perseverance and connect it to their own experience of overcoming a challenge?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job! Patricia Polacco couldn't read when she was little, but she worked so hard and became a famous writer with over 100 books. Remember, never give up on yourself, because you can do amazing things!

parent_notes: This is one of the most powerful read-alouds in children's literature. Patricia Polacco is dyslexic, and this book tells her real story of struggling with reading until 5th grade, when Mr. Falker recognized her intelligence and got her specialized help. It is particularly meaningful at the end of the primary year because the child can reflect on their own growth. The honey-on-the-book scene (a Jewish tradition) can prompt discussion of how different cultures celebrate learning. If your child has struggled with any aspect of learning, this book validates that struggle and celebrates the breakthrough. Have tissues handy — this one gets parents too.
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
extension_ideas: Draw a favorite scene
Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together
